Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (New York, NY) in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions:
The night before the interview a recruiter emailed me some “interview prep” material. I reviewed it the next morning and found three “cases” which were just vague descriptions of their company processes and products and how I would improve them.
The interview kicked off and without showing any interest in knowing more about me or telling me more about their company they wanted me to do a presentation based on almost no information provided. My assumption was that my ability to get the details from them would be part of the test but, no, the more questions I asked, the more they seemed to feel I wasn’t understanding the point of what of what I was being tested on. They wanted a show they could critique.
And that’s really the problem here - it wasn’t an interview it was a test. It wasn’t respectful, it wasn’t human or even good business. It was just a way to see what kind of show I could give.
I work in machine learning and healthcare with a very large company and have been in many interviews of which I can’t think of a single one where the people and the format was this annoying and disrespectful.
It’s a good thing though, as we parted ways five minutes in. This must a godawful place to work if that’s how they treat people. Good riddance.

Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health

1) This company has just rolled out a process with pre-determined (mostly behavioral) questions: of which the interviewers just read off the rubric, popcorn-style, and evaluate.  It doesn't appear as if the questions change between panels, which means you are answering the same ones repeatedly to different groups.  There was one interviewer who deviated slightly and asked questions which built off prior responses, which allowed for more natural and reciprocal dialogue.  After multiple rounds of this, it's apparent that this style was chosen (at least in part) to decrease the candidate's ability to assess individual/group-based culture while increasing the company's own ability to do so to the candidate.  This is the company's perogative to hold their hand close to their chest while asking differently of a potential team member, of course, but given their alleged emphasis on collegiality it's an unusual move.

2) For the second in-person: while the speed of response was great, requesting less than 24-hour availability the night of the particularly bad snowstorm this year... during the week of Thanksgiving?

3) Sending thank-you notes through Human Resources to be forwarded instead of directly to the interviewers, long after the recruiter had a hand in the process, was something I have never encountered before.  Unsure if that's corporate policy.

title: Data Analyst-Population Health Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Jan 2018
Interview Descriptions:
I actually interviewed with the Population Health Analytics team three separate times for three separate positions. (Internships and full-time positions). The results were always sort of the same:  

0. They will come to your state university and feed you pizza and tell you they are interested in applicants. 

1. The manager calls you up for a phone screen.

2. If you pass the phone screen, they call you in for a small group interview.

3. You will wait several months to hear if you were hired.

4. The manager will send out a blanket email saying that they were looking for someone with more experience. 

5. You will look on LinkedIn and realize that they hired someone with less education and experience than you had. 

Be warned, if you are a Utah State University graduate student, they will want to use their alumni connections to pretend like they are interested in hiring you. They are not. Eat their free pizza and chalk it up to a free meal. They will invariably hire a Brigham Young University student. (Which I'm actually fine with; BYU is the much superior program and school). 

In the actual interviews, they will ask you to describe projects you have worked on. The best projects are ones that you used basic regression and classification techniques to perform an interesting, but routine, task with statistics. They are not research statisticians and do not care about *research* you have performed. They want you to speak about business and customer outcomes.  As long as you are fundamentally sound on basic statistics, they are not going to ask you any questions that you cannot answer. 

You may be asked to do some simple programming in R. Know how to use glm() in R. Knowing some support vector (e1071) stuff may also be helpful. 

It overall looked like a nice enough place to work. Pretty clean. Do note that the pay is likely not amazing. (Based on what I could dredge up, they will pay you maybe 80% market value. Maybe less).
Interview Questions: What is your greatest failure in life?

title: Senior Incestment Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions:

I was a very good fit for this role, exactly as per description.
The 'funny stuff' has started happening after the interview.
Immediately after my visit I did follow-up with a nice and short 'thank you' letter to the hiring manager re-affirming my interest and positive experience based on my visit. That was the last week of May 2016. Then there was a long, very long silence. After about three weeks I had decided to follow-up again with another e-mail re-affirming my interest.
About 10 days later, a letter with a request for five (5!!! direct and recent!) recommendations came. sure enough, they outsourced this process to another firm that has the references to register (!) and upload their letters (!!) into their system... Leaving aside the fact that one can get direct positive recommendations from five people in organization one is currently employed in, without jeopardizing current employment, is only one's firm wants to get rid of you. Besides, even if it was reasonable to find five references (which I did), who is going to bother with going some place, uploading something? How would I know if they did? Anyway, I have been able to get the references completed.
A month later another HR person finally got back with me saying that the 'original' HR person was on leave, and she could not reach me by phone (granted, I did have my personal phone die on a trip I took)... but she did not even bother to write an e-mail... duh? Okay, with that 'confusion' out of the way... took another good two weeks to receive a call back verbally confirming that I was the best candidate (for what I know they could have interviewed a sizable squad of people over that period of time, it was already the very end of June!)... Well, so far so good? The HR person kind of relegated the responsibility for the delays to the hiring manager, so that they 'work together with a Consultant to work out an offer' for me (???)... Then some random phone calls from HR started, with no apparent goals. They made it seem that the offer of some kind is being put together, but no talk of a starting date, or anything relevant, was done.
I kindly said that the salary figure looked acceptable to me, and that I would like to receive an offer. The HR drone said it would be coming in '15 minutes'... Needless to say, did I get to see it in 15 minutes, or by the end of that day, or the next Monday. This was already ridiculous beyond any reason. 
Finally, now that the 'offer' came as an e-mail from the HR, that had only the salary in it, and no (nada!) any vital information about pretty much any other conditions of the employment. No formal letter, no signatures of any kind, not even a copy to a Hiring manager or anyone with any kind of executive latitude.
At this point, what I think is going on is they have their own 'right' candidate but they need me out of the way voluntarily, as the panel has chosen me in the interview process, so they >> have to << try and hire me, but if they make it ridiculous I would just move on and they invite their brother in faith (or a cousin three times removed, who knows?) with open arms.
Well, I am not giving this kind of satisfaction :) I am waiting for that offer. Still waiting. Needless to say I won't be going to work in that spider can - just want come closure for myself.
Update: It's September, I finally turned that thing down. This was ridiculous.

If they like your from your application and first interview there is a second interview with another manager to determine qualifications. After that their is either a job offer or not one.
Interview Questions: describe a time when you failed at something.

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Murray, UT) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions:
I applied online then walked in a few days later to introduce myself.  Got an interview for a couple days later. HR contacted me by phone that same day (on a Friday) to let me know they wanted to continue with the hiring process and to see if it was ok to contact my references. Got a call that Monday from the HR Recruiter offering me the job and giving me more information on the orientation process. 

From online application to job offer was 15 days. From introduction to job offer was 12 days. From introduction to interview was 2 days. From interview to reference check was 3 hours. From interview/reference check to job offer was 3 days. 

Interview was 1:1. Interviewer was my potential manager who was very easy to talk to, light-hearted, and just so approachable (which really helped to calm my nerves).
Interview Questions: What are your career goals? -and- What do you look for in a job?

title: Recruitment Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: You apply online.  The recruiter called with some questions.  She was very upbeat and helpful.  She explained the process to me.  The interview was scheduled very quickly.  I knew exactly where to go and who I was meeting with.  During the interview I received information about what the job entailed.  Those interviewing were also friendly and informative.  They helped me feel comfortable and confident.  They asked good questions that helped them get to know me, my skills, and my ways of handling situations.  They got back to me in a timely manner!
Interview Questions: It can take time to get all the necessary clearances to hire the candidate.  What would you do to help the process?

title: Applications Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: Had the phone interview, and felt it went well. Was told I would hear back within the week, seemed like a positive fit. Was told my qualifications were a good fit even though I lacked one of the "nice-to-haves". Later learned I'd been out of the running because of my qualifications not being an exact fit. The HR department takes the "screening for exact fit" a little too seriously, and is probably screening out the best candidates for the job.
Interview Questions: Describe a success at work

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Murray, UT) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview was over the phone, and asked basic html, css and javascript questions. They also wanted to know if i was familiar with java and jquery. The interview was only done over the phone, i never met anybody until my first day of work.
Interview Questions: What is a javascript callback?

title: NICU TECH Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Ogden, UT) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: short and sweet. I have never had an interview that lasts for more than fifteen minutes there. Normally you are there with just the manager but on occasion they will have a panel of people
Interview Questions: they asked what the intermountain healing commitments were and to describe a time I used customer service

title: RN Home Health Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: Met the recruiters at a job fair and gave them a resume. They called the next day to set up an interview. I made an appointment for early the next week. Arrived early, but had to wait till past the scheduled time. Interviewed with someone other than the person originally scheduled to do the interview.
Interview Questions: They asked about critical thinking skills, and time management.

title: Orderly Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Murray, UT) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: Was brief but very professional. Took a long time to hear back from company to schedule interview. I applied in April, interviewed in May, and started in June. This is the perfect job for college students.
Interview Questions: Why are you best for this job?

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: Two week process after the interview. HR will call with an offer. The interview consistent of 3 supervisors and mangers of the unit. Each asked questions and wrote your response down. You are given points based on your answers. You should have knowledge of nursing skills as I did have questions regarding basic nursing skills and dx's.  Good luck.
Interview Questions: Describe a situation where  you provided excellent customer service in your current position?

title: Managerial Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was a final candidate for a managerial position at Intermountain Medical Center.  The first interview was with three people, the person who would be my direct supervisor, her superior, and an employee.  The second interview was with a group of 6 managers.  The third and final interview was just with the supervisor.  By that time I knew I didn't want the job, and I basically let her know that.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time that yo u had to work with someone you didn't get along with.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: The process was professional. I received an email informing me of the opportunity to interview by phone. After the phone interview, I was emailed to come in and interview in person. It was 2:1 with the director of finance and a manager. After a week, the skills test was foregone and I was notified that I had not made the cut.
Interview Questions: Describe a time when you have had to manage multiple projects that compete for your time.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: My internship interview was managed by several people, each one at a time in the room. My final interview included two people- one from a recruiter perspective and one manager of a team.
Interview Questions: What kind of position do you envision yourself in?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: I first interviewed on the phone with a senior manager, then I interviewed with two members of senior management twice. It was a technical interview with direct questions about my ability in Database administration, CSS/HTML, Java, Javascript, and general application coding and design, but definitely felt that the interviewers were more interested in me as a person, my soft skill, and if I would make a good contribution to the company culture.
Interview Questions: What is your experience with java?

title: Executive- Senior Vice President Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: Broken promises, failed commitments. Too many red flags in position and leadership team and I believe that they already had a candidate to offer the position to and I was extraneous baggage. Offered to answer questions, but did not respond. They may have also been fishing for competitive information that I did not provide. I have no idea what the final outcome is as the HR team will not respond or even acknowledge receipt of expenses which were substantial and they had failed to make arrangements for, resulting in my outlay. They are small and will likely be swallowed in a few years so not a place to spend time
Interview Questions: They were fishing for competitive information

title: Content Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: I kind of networked my way into the position and they happened to have a position open that fit my skills. I had two informal "informational interviews" with members of management, a phone interview with a recruiter, and a formal interview that took a little over four hours with several members of our department.
Interview Questions: Why healthcare?

title: Patient Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (South Jordan, UT) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very positive.  I was asked a total of 6 questions that were all behavioral based.  There were 3 representatives in the room and each took a turn to ask a question.
Interview Questions: Describe a time when you were confronted with a difficult situation with a co-worker, and how did you handle it?

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Lakewood, CO) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: Phone screen conducted by HR. Interviewer's questions and response to my answers showed negativity to the point where I had to question why they interviewed me in the first place.
Interview Questions: What did your last boss consider to be your weakest characteristic?

title: I Interviewed to Get Into Their Phlebotomy Training Program Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Murray, UT) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed by two women who headed the phlebotomy programs at two different Intermountain hospitals. One of them was cold and jumped all over the fact that I asked about career advancement at her hospital. The interview was a little high pressure because they were only accepting so many into the program and there were two of them throwing questions at you. I feel like they were looking for people in their twenties who were pretty inexperienced and had no ambition whatsoever. Would I say Intermountain is ageist? Yeah, I would.
Interview Questions: How did I handle a management dispute?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: I went through five meetings over several weeks.  After the phone screening, there was a skills test that consisted of printed sheets describing what they wanted me to do in specific programs, and then I met with different people on four other occasions.  To their benefit they didn't leave me wondering what was happening.  The recruiter kept in touch to let me know I was still under consideration.  I sort of wonder if I only got the offer because I was the only left hanging on after all that time.  Hehe!
Interview Questions: If I was on a trip and called you saying I hated my hotel room, how would you handle it?

title: Digital Team Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions:
I applied in the midst of a department restructing, so the "duration of the process" was a little longer than usual. However, once the ball got rolling, it was fairly quick and the HR Rep did a fabulous job keeping me in the loop on the next steps and where SCL Health was in their process. 
I had 1) an HR Phone Screening call, 2) a 1-on-1 call with the hiring Director, and 3) an in person interview with my future director and the department VP, and finally 4) an in person interview with my future director and the two other department directors. 

By the time I was done, I felt very comfortable in knowing who I would work with daily, our department's leadership style and personalities, the Mission, Vision and Values of the system and of the specific department in which I would work.
Interview Questions: Behavior based questions ... (i.e. Tell me about a time when X-Y-Z or a situation where X-Y-Z)

title: Register Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Wheat Ridge, CO) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: I went to a job fair and sat down with several people. I was called the next day and it was a quicker process than I expected as I was offered the position and in orientation within 3 weeks.
Interview Questions: Where do you expect to see yourself in 5 years?

title: Marketing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: Started with screening from HR representative. That was about a 30 minute call. HR rep was very nice and polite. Fairly straight forward questions about background and provided info on role. That lead to an in person interview which lasted about an hour. Questions focused on skills rather than behavioral type questions.  Followed up with hiring manager but never received an official email or letter that they went with another candidate.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: Application accepted and interview scheduled within 2 weeks.  Interview was group type with typical questions. The manager was honest about expectations. HR contacted me by phone with initial offer then with written offer.
Interview Questions: Experience, philosophy of patient care.

title: Patient Care Tech - Pediatrics Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Intermountain Health in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions:
I applied online and got a login . I had applied for a couple other jobs with no success.
For this job application I had a cover letter and experience as a CNA for 6 months. I also worked at a daycare for 3 years which I think really helped. I called their HR department and three days later got a call from the HR lady about an interview. had a single interviewee who luckily was very friendly and easy to talk to. She asked easy questions. For example "Tell me about yourself".
Interview Questions: How working in a team helps you succeed? What are three things you can leave me with that will help me choose you over other candidates.

title: Specialist, Digital Services Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: About three weeks after I submitted my application, a representative from HR reached out to organize a phone interview with the hiring manager. The hiring manager called and asked five questions ranging from past work experiences, what I would aim to complete first if I were selected for the position, and even where I saw myself in a few years, I waited another three weeks until I had my in-person interview at the corporate office. Once I completed that, they were very transparent about the number of candidates they had left to interview. I wasn't sure who I'd hear back from next, but I was honored to hear from the Senior Vice President and Chief Communications and Marketing Officer about joining the team!
Interview Questions:
Where do you see yourself in a couple years?
What is one of the first things you'd do in the position?

title: RN COORDINATOR Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Saint George, UT) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: Lengthy process which included the nurse residency program, simulation trainings, and a highly competitive competition.  I also had to undergo training and orientation to the CVU, ICU, medoncology units, and BHU.
Interview Questions: When would you deviate from protocol

title: Environmental Services Aide Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: I went into the EVS office and interviewed with the then manager of the whole office. It was quick and pain free. He was nice and I just really needed that job.
Interview Questions: If you see a patient looking lost or hurt, could you help them?

title: Desktop Support Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (West Valley City, UT) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: I met with the manager, supervisors, and a few team members. We exchanged questions and answers about the position and my abilities and skills. We also talked over the position and what I would be doing.
Interview Questions: What do I do for the Army.

title: Human Resources Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview with the recruiter, then hiring manger, then one in-person interview. I had a good experience, recruiters were very responsive and interview team was professional and friendly. I felt they asked fair questions and were very honest answering my questions. Overall, I was very pleased with the experience and decided to take the position and have been very happy here.
Interview Questions: Least favorite job you have had and why.

title: Psychiatric Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Ogden, UT)
Interview Descriptions: I don't remember how long it took after applying online to hear back from them, but when I was called the interview was scheduled for a couple of weeks after. I was surprised and a bit intimidated to find that there would be three staff members interviewing me, but my fears were quickly allayed as they were all very pleasant and brought out the best in me. It felt very casual and was actually kind of fun. The interview lasted maybe 20-25 minutes. They said they would let me know if I got the job by the end of the next week, but later that day called for references, and the day after the interview I was offered the job.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you went above and beyond for a patient.

title: TAC Analyst I Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: I was recommended by a friend, but SCL went through a contract company, who then contacted me. I was a contractor for 6 months and then hired on full time with SCL. From what I can tell they no longer use the contracting company anymore and hire directly through SCL. I had 1 phone interview, and 1 in person interview.
Interview Questions: A few technical questions here and there threw me for a loop, mostly because I was not in front of a PC and speaking to them on the phone so it was difficult for me to explain step by step how I would resolve the issue.

title: CNA Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions: I applied the job through the company website. It took about 2 and half weeks to get a response. It was one on one and the interviewer was really nice to talk with.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself.

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions:
Applied through career fair. Got a call from a recruiter to visit their office in Murray. There were about 30 candidates.They showed us around and talked about the work that was being done their. 
Then took us to meet with managers one by one and we had our interviews. After that they gave us lunch. Whole process was about 3-4 hours.
Interview Questions: Basic HR type questions. Hypothetical scenarios regarding work place conflicts and how you would handle them. Talk about projects that you have done in school.

title: Sourcing Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: Very Friendly interview and accommodating with date and time of interview. They were very clear that the company was moving about this time next year. Felt like they really wanted to know about my work history.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Physical Therapist Assistant (Aquatic) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: Had a brief phone interview followed by a second phone interview in which 3 therapists (2 PT's and one PTA) asked questions. After the second interview I was invited to fly out to Salt Lake City for an in-person interview...on my own dime, which I did.  A recruiter called me about 1 1/2 months after the in-person interview to tell me that I did not get the job and that they had a hard time deciding between me and the person that they hired. I was glad that they at least called me instead of sending me a generic email like most companies do. The recruiter was also open to answering questions regarding interview feedback which was helpful.  Most companies want nothing to do with you after they send a rejection email. The respect was appreciated.
Interview Questions: Mostly scenario questions about how you would interpret a PT's note and how to progress a pt.

title: End User Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Billings, MT) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: The hiring process takes some time. About a month or so I think is about how long it took to get through interviews and such. Pretty straight forward interview questions.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years

title: IT Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was quite normal.  I initially was screened by the HR rep who asked me traditional questions about my previous experience and schooling, my interest in the position, etc.  After getting the green light from the HR rep I was then asked the following day to interview with the hiring manager in person.  We had a delightful conversation and talked about how my experience and schooling is a great match.  I was made an offer, at a very low hourly rate that was non-negotiable.  I took the job for the experience; however, I wish i had taken a job with better pay, especially since full-time positions with IHC provide horrible base pay and benefits - unless you are coming into a high leadership position - SVP or higher.
Interview Questions: Tell about a time you...

title: Patient Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: Applications are submitted online.  More than half are rejected based on whether or not you answer the correct questions.  Once selected there are usually 2 interviews followed by an official job offer via phone call and email.  The work environment varies on the clinic.  I worked in 2 clinics.  The first was very positive.  The physicians, MA, rad tech and receptionists all view each other as equals. As such patient care and service was at its best.  At the 2nd clinic the MA viewed the receptionists as lower individuals and it created a very difficult environment.
Interview Questions: Difficulty with different insurance companies and their policies regarding care.  It is hard to know what company covers what.

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: It depends on what area of the company you are applying for. Interviews vary from casual setting to picky. Some departments at Intermountain Healthcare are more interested in "clicking with you" to find out if you will be a good fit with the team.  Other areas will pick your resume apart and ask about any or all formal training the candidate has that qualifies he or she to do the job. Some teams will have a scenario that you need to explain how you would work, etc. Often I found the hiring manager already had an internal candidate in mind, and my interview was just so they can fill out paperwork to make HR happy, and to avoid a lawsuit later. If you are lucky to get an in-person interview, watch for the interaction.  If some of the employees on the panel don't care to interact much with you, it is because they are just going through the motions.
Interview Questions: Give me an example of a time when you...

title: CNA Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT)
Interview Descriptions: After submitting the application, I had a group interview. The interview questions were related to the position, my abilities, and my personality. I interviewed at on off site campus that was easy to find. I received a call within two weeks offering me the position. I then set up orientation to learn the organization's practices and policies.
Interview Questions: I did not have previous experience, as the hardest question for me to answer was regarding why I would be good for the job without experience.

title: Social Worker Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Cedar City, UT) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: After the position closed, I received a letter inviting me to an interview.  The time and place were very specific.  I was interviewed by three individuals, including the current Hospital Social Worker.  It took about 20 minutes.  There were several other candidates who were interviewed as well.  I received a letter to let me know that another candidate had been chosen.
Interview Questions: How my past experience has prepared me for a position as a hospital social worker.

title: Pharmacy Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: Only one interview with a panel. I submitted through website and then the recruiter called. Set up the appointment. Got the job. The people I interviewed with were fantastic! There was a bit of time though on the response as to whether or not I got the job. Overall i feel like it was a great learning experience.
Interview Questions: The question about if I had used Pivot tables

title: End User Analyst II Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: Manager and Supervisor asked me about my various experience. Manager Gavin, seemed like he was high as a kite during the interview. He also did not really seem interested in my answers and stated he had to leave 1/2 way through.
Interview Questions: There were not any difficult or unexpected questions during this interview.

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: Informed of the job opening from a friend and passed the HR screening software and the phone interview. That was followed up by an interview with 6-8 people where they asked me technical questions regarding the work I would performing in addition to soft questions like, "Give me an example of a time when you successfully managed conflict."
Interview Questions: They asked me specific questions about Oracle SQL syntax ( when does it make sense to use a 'With' statement to optimize query performance)

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Mar 2014
Interview Descriptions: Interview was very easy, the company takes time to verify all claims and references. They had a number of people I would be working with closely in the interview. Later they told me one of the guys didn't show up for work (probably used their offer to get a better one). I was also offered a pay well above the minimum I specified in my application. This company is serious about staying competitive and retaining their employees. They go as far as using third party companies to research the current pay in the market to do both high initial pay offers and to raise current employees pay even without them asking for it. This is a the first time I've ever seen this.
Interview Questions: Multiple question geared towards figuring out how well I would work with the team and how willing I am to study new things.

title: HIM Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: Intermountain Healthcare is a prestegious healthcare provider. They look for the best candidates possible so the interview process is a little different than a normal interview. Be prepared for personal experience questions along with behavioral questions as well.
Interview Questions: Explain a time when you had to work with a difficult co-worker to meet a departmental goal?

title: RN Staff Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Logan, UT) in Feb 2014
Interview Descriptions: It was mostly to see how well I would work with the team and to give an example of my critical thinking. I was pretty much a new grad with just working in a nursing home for 5 months. I think they mostly wanted to see if I was teachable, willing to work with others, and if I could work with people who were rough around the edges.
Interview Questions: Give an example of what you did in an acute situation. What do you do when working with a difficult colleague.

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Salt Lake City, UT) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: Sat down in a room with the hiring manager and an employee, I was asked about basic project management skills. I answered the questions. Half way through the interview there was an activity to find out how you would do in particular scenarios.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you worked with information technology and how it worked out?

title: Associate Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: Online process.  Fairly straightforward.
Interview Questions: Describe a mistake you have made in the workforce.

title: Physician Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: One interview, 30 mins long with 4 interviewers including regional rep. About 15 questions.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a situation where the outcome didn't turn out the way you expected?

title: Registere Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Provo, UT)
Interview Descriptions: My initial interview was a "group interview" where they brought a bunch of people in together. I'm pretty sure that the point of the interview was just to see how you interact with others in the various activities.  They also told us all to give a short (~3 minute) presentation on "anything you want".  They really do mean "anything".  It could be making a Peanut Butter sandwich.  It could be your hobby.  It could be an interesting medical technology that is just coming out.  It's less about the content and more about how you carry yourself.
Interview Questions: "If you were a vehicle, what would you be and why?"

title: Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Provo, UT)
Interview Descriptions: A little intimidating. The second interview was with the whole team -- about 7 people. Took about 6 weeks total.
Interview Questions: I wish I could remember....

title: Phlebotomist Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Oct 2013
Interview Descriptions: I applied online  and  they called me for interview.Hiring process took one month.After the interview I called supervisor to get a reply.Finally she called me as I am selected.They offer me  pay less than what I expected..
Interview Questions: Are you able to work with different Nationality?

title: Cancer Registrar Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Intermountain Health (Denver, CO) in Oct 2013
Interview Descriptions: The hiring process included a telephone interview, an interview with manager and a group interview.  The telephone interview was very easy. Asked why I wanted to leave current company.  The one on one interview went well.  It was more of a getting to know you type interview.  The group interview was a lot harder as there were about five people throwing questions at me.  Just was very honest and did the best I could.  Many times the group interviews are to check your skills but also to see if you will fit in with the team.
Interview Questions: The basic questions such as what do you like least about current job, how to handle angry physicians.

title: Phlebotomist I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: The interview I was scheduled for was a group interview with the phlebotomy department manager and the phlebotomy shift manager. It was a straight forward review. They asked specific questions about my past experience, what I thought my weaknesses were, and why I thought I was the best candidate for the position.
Interview Questions: Be prepared to be tested on your knowledge of the tools.

title: Research Support Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Intermountain Health
Interview Descriptions: The interview was a panel interview consisting of two staff members from the department and the department manager. Interview Descriptions: The hiring process was not at all difficult. I was made to feel very comfortable, and at ease. There were two rounds of interviews with two individuals in each round. The whole process took about a week and a half to complete. All in all the process was very simple and easy.
